subject: More stuff on Clearscript
msgSnippet: Just a short note to say thanks to And. Rosta, John Cowan, and Kyudosha (Andy). I haven t yet went through and made the final vowel- symbol assignment (it s
messageBody:
Just a short note to say "thanks" to And. Rosta, John Cowan, and
Kyudosha (Andy). I haven't yet went through and made the final vowel-
symbol assignment (it's hard!) but I think I've got the consonants
straightend out.

I've made sure that the symbols for the "S" and "Z" (which looked
like E and 3) sounds were clearly unvoiced/voiced variants without
being mirror images, which meant grabbing the symbol originally meant
for the "ch" in loch (looks like a lambda) and it's rotated image.
I've made the "l" and "r" sounds so they were clearly not just
unvoiced/voiced versions of each other, though I have kept it so the
appear related.

In response to Kyudosha's suggestion, I've pushed "middle" vowel
symbols either high or low -- symbols that were mirror images or
rotations were split to maximize distinction. OK, so I didn't go all
out and place all the vowels on the writing line (grin), at least not
yet. I want to play around a bit with the vowels I finally decide on
before committing to one format or another.

If anyone would like to take a peek at the alphabet so far, check out:
www.mrouse.com/rousalph.htm

Further suggestions can be posted here or sent to:
mrouse@...

Thanks again!

Mike Rouse
mrouse@...

As a postscript, anyone and everyone may freely use all or part of
the alphabet for their own projects, either as-is or altered however
they want. My only request is that my name is mentioned if more than
half of it is used. I don't see any mass stampede to use this
alphabet, despite its clearly superior nature (grin), but this is
just in case someone in the future wants to have fun with what I've
done.

Just a short note to say "thanks" to And. Rosta, John Cowan, and 
Kyudosha (Andy). I haven't yet went through and made the final vowel-
symbol assignment (it's hard!) but I think I've got the consonants 
straightend out.

I've made sure that the symbols for the "S" and "Z" (which looked 
like E and 3) sounds were clearly unvoiced/voiced variants without 
being mirror images, which meant grabbing the symbol originally meant 
for the "ch" in loch (looks like a lambda) and it's rotated image. 
I've made the "l" and "r" sounds so they were clearly not just 
unvoiced/voiced versions of each other, though I have kept it so the 
appear related.

In response to Kyudosha's suggestion, I've pushed "middle" vowel 
symbols either high or low -- symbols that were mirror images or 
rotations were split to maximize distinction. OK, so I didn't go all 
out and place all the vowels on the writing line (grin), at least not 
yet. I want to play around a bit with the vowels I finally decide on 
before committing to one format or another.

If anyone would like to take a peek at the alphabet so far, check out:
www.mrouse.com/rousalph.htm

Further suggestions can be posted here or sent to: 
mrouse@...

Thanks again!

Mike Rouse
mrouse@...

As a postscript, anyone and everyone may freely use all or part of 
the alphabet for their own projects, either as-is or altered however 
they want. My only request is that my name is mentioned if more than 
half of it is used. I don't see any mass stampede to use this 
alphabet, despite its clearly superior nature (grin), but this is 
just in case someone in the future wants to have fun with what I've 
done.
